title: Author
text:
Currently a postdoctoral associate with responsibilities as both a lead instructor and researcher at Duke University. 
Training and over 8 years experience in both developing and instructing in-person and online courses in statistics and data science that range from 30 through 170 students.
Current research focuses on how to better the teaching and learning experiences for those involved. Other research interests include sports analytics and creating dynamic tools to support data driven decision making.

title: Hello World!
text:
Explore with Shiny: Creating a Statistics Inquiry-Based Learning Tool
       with undergraduate Alina Yin
Creating a Data Science Specialization in Coursera
       with Dr. Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel
Introductory Data Science: A Blueprint to Navigate Curricular, Pedagogical, and Computational Challenges
       with Dr. Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel
Motivation Matters: Developing an Instrument to Measure Newer Instructors’ Situational Motivation to Use Active Learning in the Classroom when Teaching Statistics
       with Dr. Jennifer Green
Data Driven Disc Golf: Dynamic Interactive Application to help Players Spatially Visualize a Disc Golf Course
       with Dr. Christian Stratton
Undergraduate Independent Study (Pending)




Creating a dynamic interactive shiny application in R to better students’ understanding of statistics and data science. The application focuses on bootstrapping and permutations. Our application provides students the opportunity to learn about these concepts through investigation, while simultaneously developing the needed coding skills to perform these concepts on their own.
This project aims to support teaching at Duke and other universities by continuing the advancement of statistics and data science education, specifically at the undergraduate level. Further, this application sets the foundation for future work to best understand how students learn to code and implement these processes when first being introduced to bootstrapping and permutations.
This project plans to extend to include the development of assessment questions surrounding the application.



Creating a multi-course Data Science with R specialization for Coursera. This includes modules such as: Data Visualization; Importing + Wrangling Data; Data Ethics; Modeling + Prediction; Inference. This project entails the creation of videos and assessment questions on such topics that self-enrolled students must watch and complete before earning their Data Science with R specialization.
Currently, I am in the process of creating a Data Science specialization course for Coursera, and am



Co-authoring a paper Introductory Data Science: A Blueprint to Navigate Curricular, Pedagogical, and Computational Challenges that provides a flexible blueprint for instructors to develop or redesign an introductory data science course to include a variety of technologies while simultaneously discussing how to navigate challenges such as large class sizes, and technology integration.



Understanding how self-determined their use of active learning is through their motivations to use active learning can help inform how to support newer instructors’ adoption of such techniques. Thus, we designed a five-phase study to develop an instrument that measures newer statistics instructors’ types of motivations to use active learning.
